segments.text: The military has had enough problems with divorces and things like that because when you isolate a young man during one of his very formative times in his life,
it's hardly just and i used to know a consulting marriage psychologist and he made a flat statement that marriages resulted from campus romances where they got a chance to see various people
had the highest degree of success than any other group.
So I can see nothing wrong with Gletch.
And I don't think A&M could have grown if it had been all military.
Also, during this time, of course, the first blacks came to A&M during the all-runner .
I have no objection to it.
I do not like to have black caucuses or green caucuses or ethnic caucuses.
Any student organizations?
No.
Except just to meet and visit his friends.
I object to bilingual education.
If an individual is going to be a citizen of the United States, I expect him to speak the language of the nation.
And nothing infuriates me more than go to a soda fountain and have two Latin Americans behind the counter that speak in Spanish.
Maintain some of your ethnic background is good,
If we're going to be citizens, let's all talk the same language.
What about the draft?
Do you think now, of course, with the recent registration again, what's your opinion on the professional arm?
I think it's an absolute necessity.
In other words, you'd rather have a professional volunteer service than a draft?
No, sir.
Again, it depends on the times, when the Army looks good pay-wise and times when it looks bad pay-wise.
When I joined the 6th Division in 1940, they'd been on a recruiting mission on the foothills of Arkansas and Missouri.
And probably a promise of a pair of shoes and three meals a day was a big incentive.

When times get such that the money is poor in the Army and too good on the outside, but you've got to have a level of intelligence to be able to do what you want to do, particularly the more complicated the weapons, the more complicated the communication systems are, the computers.
You can't have low IQ people doing that.
My oldest son was just 33 now.
He was kind of facing the draft.
I could have gotten him on guard, but he never asked me.
Finally, he asked me one day, and I called Austin, and they called Washington.
He called back and said, we have an agreement with General Hershey, who incidentally I knew, that once he calls him, we won't touch him.
I said, that's fair enough.
I could have gotten him to the guard.
So was he drafted?
Yes, sir.
No.
He signed up for four years in the regular army in lieu of the draft.
So he could have chosen whatever he wanted to do.
What about...
the new issue of drafting women.
What's your opinion on that?
I have mixed feelings about that.
I feel like it's just as much their country as it is mine.
I do feel like there's certain combat jobs that the majority of them are not able to
A few individuals, yes.
But there's a lot of other jobs.
They can cook.
They can clerk.
They can clean the latrines just about anybody else.
Now, from the standpoint of keeping the male and the female separated, it could be a problem.
It creates a discord.
But I feel like it's their country, just like it is mine.
So do you think they should be driving?
Yes.
But I don't think they should be in front lines.
I'm basically out of questions for this interview.
Is there anything that you feel that I've missed about your career that we should talk about?
You trained me to drive.
know about what my philosophies are and why my feelings are.
I'm still kind of a patriot now, I guess.
I think this is the finest country in the world, even in spite of our mistakes.
We're a nation of laws, not men.
All men get in the way sometimes, but it doesn't matter.
OK, well, thank you very much, sir.
